citeinfo.title: Evidence for an Early Recent Warm Interval in Northwestern Alaska

abstract.p: A warm interval that began at least 10,000 years ago and lasted until at least 8,300 years ago is recorded in the coastal tundra covered area of northwestern Alaska by the presence of fossil wood of tree size or tree species, fossil beaver-gnawed wood found beyond the modern range of beaver, evidence of ice-wedge melting, buried soils and soils that extend below the top of modern permafrost.

[Reference: McCulloch, D. and Hopkins, D., 1966, Evidence for an early recent warm interval 10,000 to 8,300 years ago in northern Alaska: Geological Society of America Bulletin, v. 77, no. 10, p. 1089-1108.]
This journal article can be found at the University of Washington Natural Sciences Library.

descript.purpose: To show evidence early recent warm interval in Northwestern Alaska
